description: From Middle English del, dele, from Old English d«£l (‚Äúpart, share, portion‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *daili, from Proto-Germanic *dailiz (‚Äúpart, deal‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *d ∞ail- (‚Äúpart, watershed‚Äù).

Cognate with Scots dele (‚Äúpart, portion‚Äù), West Frisian diel (‚Äúpart, share‚Äù), Dutch deel (‚Äúpart, share, portion‚Äù), German Teil (‚Äúpart, portion, section‚Äù), Danish del (‚Äúpart‚Äù), Swedish del ("part, portion, piece") Icelandic deila (‚Äúdivision, contention‚Äù), Gothic êå≥êå∞êåπêåªêçÉ (dails, ‚Äúportion‚Äù), Slovene del (‚Äúpart‚Äù). Related to Old English dƒÅl (‚Äúportion‚Äù). More at dole.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A division, a portion, a share, a part, a piece.
examples: Synonyms: allotment, apportionment, distribution
We gave three deals of grain in tribute to the king.

entries.meaning: (often followed by of) An indefinite quantity or amount; a lot (now usually qualified by great or good).
examples: Synonyms: batch, flock, good deal, great deal, hatful, heap, load, lot, mass, mess, mickle, mint, muckle, peck, pile, plenty, pot, quite a little, raft, sight, slew, spate, stack, tidy sum, wad, whole lot, whole slew; see also Thesaurus:lot

description: From Middle English delen, from Old English d«£lan (‚Äúto divide, part‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *dailijan, from Proto-Germanic *dailijanƒÖ (‚Äúto divide, part, deal‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *d ∞ail- (‚Äúpart, watershed‚Äù).

entries.meaning: (archaic in general sense) An act of dealing or sharing out.
(card games) The distribution of cards to players; a player's turn for this.
examples: Synonym: hand
I didn‚Äôt have a good deal all evening.
I believe it's your deal.

entries.meaning: A particular instance of trading (buying or selling; exchanging; bartering); a transaction.
examples: Synonyms: business deal, sale, trade, transaction
We need to finalise the deal with Henderson by midnight.
recognizing the societal deal between capital and labor regarding retirement savings

entries.meaning: (in particular) A transaction offered which is financially beneficial; a bargain.
examples: Synonyms: steal, bargain

entries.meaning: An agreement between parties; an arrangement.
examples: Synonyms: contract, pact

entries.meaning: (informal) A situation, occasion, or event.
examples: What's the deal here?
Their new movie is the biggest deal of the year.
I don't think that's such a big deal.

entries.meaning: (informal) A thing, an unspecified or unidentified object.
examples: The deal with four tines is called a pitchfork.

verbs.description: deal (third-person singular simple present deals, present participle dealing, simple past and past participle dealt or (nonstandard) dealed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To distribute among a number of recipients, to give out as one‚Äôs portion or share.
examples: Synonyms: apportion, divvy up, share, share out, portion out
The fighting is over; now we deal out the spoils of victory.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To administer or give out, as in small portions.
examples: Synonyms: administer, allot, deal out, dish out, dispense, distribute, dole out, hand out, lot, mete out, parcel out, shell out

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To distribute cards to the players in a game.
examples: I was dealt four aces.
The cards were shuffled, and the croupier dealt.

entries.meaning: (transitive) deliver damage, a blow, strike or cut. To inflict.
examples: The boxer was dealt a blow to the head.

entries.meaning: (baseball) To pitch.
examples: Synonyms: pitch, throw
The whole crowd waited for him to deal a real humdinger.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To have dealings or business.
(intransitive) To conduct oneself, to behave.
(obsolete, intransitive) To take action; to act.
(intransitive) To trade professionally (followed by in).
examples: Synonyms: sell, trade, bargain
She deals in gold.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To sell, especially to sell illicit drugs.
examples: Synonym: sell
This club takes a dim view of members who deal drugs.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be concerned with.
(intransitive) To handle, to manage, to cope.
examples: I can't deal with this.
I don't think he wants to go. ‚Äî Yeah, well, we're going anyway, and he can deal.

description: From Middle English dele (‚Äúplank‚Äù), from Middle Low German dele, from Old Saxon thili, ultimately from Proto-Germanic *√æilj«≠ (‚Äúplank, board‚Äù); cognate with Old English √æille. Doublet of thill.

entries.meaning: Made of deal.
examples: A plain deal table

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Wood that is easy to saw (from conifers such as pine or fir).
examples: Some Houses were  [‚Ä¶]  entirely lock‚Äôd up, the Doors padlockt, the Windows and Doors having Deal Boards nail‚Äôd over them,

entries.meaning: (countable) A plank of softwood (fir or pine board).
(countable, archaic) A wooden board or plank, usually between 12 or 14 feet in length, traded as a commodity in shipbuilding.
(a) Male genitalia.
examples: He saw my deal!
